Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Systematics, diversification, and functional maintenance of trophic mode in Russula (Russulales)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Comparative genomic sequence data from fungal species are beginning to provide insights into the crucial ecological roles fungi serve in nature. Recent studies suggest a major class of fungi that associate with plants as root symbionts, called ectomycorrhizal fungi, likely influence the cycling of organic carbon in nature. This research seeks to investigate the evolution of the ability to decompose organic compounds in the diverse fungal family, Russulaceae. The project will produce genome sequence data from species across the family to test how species and groups within the Russulaceae are related to each other, the ecological roles these fungi serve in nature, and how the traits that govern these ecological roles have evolved. One graduate student will be trained and a series of workshops will train undergraduates in new molecular methods and genome analysis techniques. This research will also promote interdisciplinary collaboration through established international networks between scientists in Europe, Canada, Asia, and the U.S. Genomic data from this study has the potential to lead to advances in biofuel production within fungi.

This project will produce a new molecular systematic framework for Russula, Russulaceae, and Russulales through the application of phylogenetic and phylogenomic methods, which will enable the classification of novel diversity for additional systematic studies. This study will also identify genes within the genomes of the Russulales that encode oxidoreductases and are capable of breaking down cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, and other structural plant molecules. Genomic sequence data from representative species across the Russulaceae will be generated by the Joint Genome Institute and will be assembled through the MycoCosm pipeline. Functional gene prediction will be informed by previous studies on degradative gene composition of known saprotrophs, with particular focus on those members from Russulales. Researchers will investigate functional variation throughout the lineage, emphasizing the diversity of class II peroxidases, CAZymes, and/or laccases. Evolution of functional genes will be inferred using gene family phylogenies and ancestral state reconstruction methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The family Russulaceae is an iconic family of mushroom-forming fungi because of their importance as edible mushrooms, their ectomycorrhizal (ECM) ecology as plant-root symbionts, and their high species richness in temperate and tropical regions of the world. Previous research, however, lacked a comprehensive framework by which to study and understand evolutionary relationships, patterns of diversification, and functional utility and diversity in the group. By specifically taking a lineage-based approach to the study of the Russulaceae, the dissertation addressed the biological importance of the family as a model to understand important biological patterns in ECM fungi. To this end the dissertation addressed five key areas: 1) evolutionary relationships in the Russulaceae and its placement in the order Russulales based on whole genome data; 2) biogeographic and plant association patterns across the globe; 3) factors that contributed to diversification within the genus Russula; 4) functional differences between major lineages of Russulaceae; and 5) the extent that Russulaceae have retained the ability to acquire carbon from soil organic matter.

The dissertation research combined the collection and study of fruit bodies (mushrooms) with analyses of DNA data to reconstruct evolutionary relationships and perform whole genome analyses. These efforts led to the first multi-gene phylogeny (evolutionary history) of the genus Russula. Methods of historical biogeography and models of the diversification process were employed that support the hypothesis of a temperate origin for Russula in association with groups of flowering plants such as oaks and allies. Furthermore, in contrast to expectations of inceased diversity towards the tropics, this work found that Russula is more species rich in temperate areas and that the most likely reason for this is due to higher rates of diversification in temperate areas than in the tropics. A systematic revision of the Roseinae clade in Russula revealed five new species. Lastly, a comparative genomic analysis demonstrates that Russulaceae are diverse in gene content, indicating diverse functional roles in ecosystems.
